;;T;;乌克兰春天的到来;带来了两种喘息的机会。天气变暖意味着俄罗斯对电力和天然气基础设施的疯狂导弹和无人机攻击不会那么难以忍受。随着新的温暖而来的是泥泞，大约一个月的时间军事行动变得困难。这应该会阻碍俄罗斯沿着横跨乌克兰东部和南部前线的攻击浪潮。但这不会持续太久。随着春夏之际，人们担心俄罗斯将像去年一样发起新的大规模攻势。而乌克兰这次能否阻止它，现在看起来比当时更不确定了。这就是为什么它迫切需要动员更多部队并建立更强大的前线防御。

;

;乌克兰人将自己的困境归咎于世界政客，这是可以理解的。乌克兰的西方盟友忙于中东事务、即将举行的选举和自身的经济困境，因此心烦意乱。正如我们;报道称，国会中支持特朗普的共和党人决定阻止拜登政府向乌克兰提供的610亿美元军事计划，正在对前线和乌克兰城市产生影响。乌克兰士兵被迫定量配给他们的炮弹，而俄罗斯在某些地方的火力比他们高出五比一。上周仅一晚就有超过 150 架无人机和导弹袭击了乌克兰，但乌克兰的拦截器已经所剩无几，尤其是那些能够消灭最致命入侵者的拦截器。

;;
;

;;阅读我们最近对乌克兰战争的更多报道;;

;
;

;美国的僵局有可能让俄罗斯突破乌克兰薄弱的防线。尽管法国总统埃马纽埃尔·马克龙（Emmanuel Macron）坚持认为必须击败俄罗斯，但几乎没有提供任何硬件来帮助实现这一目标，但欧洲人的表现也好不到哪儿去，而德国总理奥拉夫·肖尔茨（Olaf Scholz）也拒绝这样做。供应强大的金牛座远程导弹。欧洲未能实现本月向乌克兰提供 100 万枚炮弹的目标，尽管捷克一直在世界各地寻找机会弥补缺口。钱也是一个问题；欧洲也应该为此提供帮助。但波兰和法国等国正试图阻止乌克兰重要的农产品出口，以保护本国农民。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;但乌克兰不能简单地责怪其盟友。它也犯了错误。其中之一是人力方面的失败。俄罗斯正在准备另一波动员，着眼于下一步的大力推动。 3月22日莫斯科音乐厅发生的恐怖袭击实际上可能会让弗拉基米尔·普京(Vladimir Putin)变得更容易，他利用这次袭击来声称俄罗斯在面对嗜血的敌人时需要坚强。但在乌克兰，招募新人的尝试仍然陷入民主进程的困境。据报道，一项法案已向议会提交了 1000 多项修正案，该法案将给予政府更大的空间来筹集所需的军队。由于缺乏现金并担心不受欢迎，弗拉基米尔·泽伦斯基总统没有尽全力达到目的。

;

;乌克兰在增援方面也很晚自己的防御阵地。从某种程度上来说，这是可以理解的。政府仍然梦想着一场新的反攻，并担心当前的前线可能会变得非常像边界，从而切断该国五分之一的领土并剥夺其大部分出海通道。这条路线可能成为未来和平谈判基础的想法正是泽连斯基先生想要避免的。但现在危险如此之大，以至于这是最不坏的选择。最近几周，挖掘机已经开始移动，龙牙正在播种。它应该更早开始。祈祷现在还不算太晚。 ;■;

;;;;北极;恰好是相反的两极。第一个是被大陆包围的海洋，第二个是被海洋包围的大陆。一方面，土著人民和定居者社区；另一些则只是短暂的，停留一两个季节。自冷战以来，核武器国家一直在北极地区对峙。在同一场冲突中，为南极洲建立了和平科学合作的治理制度，其构想比外交史上的任何其他协议都更加乌托邦。北方有北极熊的威严，南方有企鹅的悲壮。两人齐心协力应对全球变暖带来的深刻剧变。但与影响北极的变化相比，那些威胁南极的变化却被大大低估了。

;

;缺乏关注的部分原因是南极洲地处偏远；那里最大的基地是美国的麦克默多基地，距最近的城市（新西兰基督城）近 4,000 公里。大多数情况下，访问者都是科学家、冒险家和支持人员。在某种程度上，也出现了停滞状态。南极洲的变化与阿拉斯加不同，阿拉斯加的永久冻土融化导致道路弯曲、建筑物倒塌。或者在西伯利亚，苔原燃烧产生的烟雾笼罩着天空，灼烧着肺部。事实上，长期以来，科学家们倾向于认为南极洲相对稳定，至少在中短期内如此。是的，它的冰原所含的水足以使海平面上升 60 米，但任何崩塌都需要几个世纪的时间。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;事实证明这是自满的。正如我们在本周的科技版中所描述的那样，地球上最大的冰箱正显示出令人震惊的大解冻迹象，这将对地球其他地区产生影响。去年南半球冬季，像格陵兰岛那么大的海冰消失等极端事件，是潜在不稳定因素加速加剧的征兆。冰川学家正在谈论“政权转变”。覆盖该大陆 98% 面积的巨大冰原之一的部分区域正在滑向海洋。

;

;水从南极洲的大陆基岩转移到海洋中。 20年前，南大洋对全球海平面上升的贡献率仅为4%。如今其份额为 12%，并且在未来几十年还将不断上升。这种效应有一个未被充分认识的推论。随着南极洲融化，其缩小的冰对邻近海域的引力减弱。这导致其他地方的海平面上升得更快。来自南极洲的海平面上升将影响澳大利亚和大洋洲，但也将不成比例地影响北美。

;

;冰盖融化不仅仅会导致海平面上升。它们还带来了延伸至赤道及更远地区的大气环流的变化，改变了萨赫勒和亚马逊地区的天气。南大洋是世界上最大的碳汇之一，每年吸收整个海洋所吸收的导致气候变化的二氧化碳的 40%。如果气候变暖，吸收的量就会减少——当数万亿吨淡水从冰冻的南方流失并改变洋流时，这种影响可能会加剧。

;

;尽管如此，一些国家仍在削减南极研究的预算。这与理性相悖。冰盖的测量和建模远远落后于大气和洋流的研究；如果要正确认识和规划恶化局势的影响，就需要快速解决这个问题。

;

;关于最迫切需要做什么以及如何最好地合作的争论- 为完成这项任务，应该激励南极条约的 56 个签署国。他们可能无法保护南极环境，而这是条约环境议定书赋予他们的义务。他们至少可以更加努力地了解他们所负责的这片空旷大陆上所发生的变化对世界其他地区意味着什么。;■;

;然而，崇拜者和批评者都很难预测具体的结果特朗普可能采取的政策。就连与他关系密切的人也承认，在他与弗拉基米尔·普京、习近平或穆罕默德·本·萨勒曼亲王等人共处一室之前，他可能不知道自己想做什么。他们声称，交易的艺术在于个人动力。然而，批评者和真正的信徒都认为，特朗普身边的人在引导他的冲动方面发挥了作用，无论是混乱的还是熟练的。因此，要了解特朗普先生可能在世界各地做什么，有必要看看他的顾问们相互竞争的意识形态。

;让美国再次变得不成熟

;

;共和党人现在已经分裂成至少三个不同的外交政策流派，借用智库欧洲外交关系委员会的分类法：优先论者、限制者和优先论者。如果特朗普再次当选总统，每个群体中至少有一些成员可能会听取他的意见。当这些群体都一致时，预测政策就相对容易。如果他们彼此不和，或者与特朗普先生的冲动不一致，政策制定就会不稳定。

;

;优先论者，罗纳德·里根的继承人，想要维护美国的全球霸权。其中包括许多“从不支持特朗普的人”，他们在保守派运动中基本上被边缘化。同样被从特朗普核心圈子中剔除的还有曾经制约他的“成年人轴心”，比如他的前幕僚长约翰·凯利(John Kelly)、前国防部长詹姆斯·马蒂斯(James Mattis)和马克·埃斯珀(Mark Esper)，以及博尔顿和另一位前国防部长。国家安全顾问，HR 麦克马斯特。

;
;
;
;

;尽管如此，一些里根派仍然站在特朗普一边，卑躬屈膝，并在必要时压制自己的信仰。其中包括迈克·蓬佩奥(Mike Pompeo)和罗伯特·奥布莱恩(Robert O'Brien)，他们分别是特朗普的最后一任国务卿和国家安全顾问，他们可能会在第二个任期内再次担任重要职务。在参议院，马可·卢比奥 (Marco Rubio)、林赛·格雷厄姆 (Lindsey Graham) 和汤姆·科顿 (Tom Cotton)——都是鹰派优先论者——仍然获得支持。

;

;反对他们的是“限制者” ，类似于过去的孤立主义者。他们认为美国不应该试图监管世界，而应该关注国内问题，特别是与墨西哥的边境问题。彻底的孤立主义者，例如竞选共和党总统提名的维韦克·拉马斯瓦米，可能只占党内精英中的少数。但它们越来越能抓住共和党选民的情绪。芝加哥外交事务委员会半个世纪以来的民意调查首次发现，大多数共和党人——尤其是特朗普先生最热心的支持者——认为美国应该远离世界事务。

;

;在优先论者和限制者之间存在着优先者，他们希望美国减少在欧洲和中东的行动，以便将资源集中在亚洲对抗中国。特朗普领导下的前五角大楼官员埃尔布里奇·科尔比(Elbridge Colby)已成为优先考虑者的大祭司。他认为，大多数美国人既没有准备好支付维持美国主导地位所需的高额国防开支，也不愿意将亚洲拱手让给中国。相反，美国必须调整优先事项，就像英国帝国在 20 世纪之交重置与法国和日本的关系以对抗崛起的德国一样。

;

;但优先考虑的群体范围很广（例如，拜登政府也表示希望重点关注中国）。其中包括科尔比等对华鹰派人士，以及俄亥俄州参议员 JD 万斯等更愿意在国内花钱而不是在国外花钱的人士。怀疑论者怀疑对中国的强调是否真的只是变相的孤立主义。那些甚至不想在乌克兰间接对抗俄罗斯的人真的准备好在台湾问题上与中国开战吗？

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;特朗普先生超越了所有三个群体。限制者将他视为自己的一员。他与他们一样希望减少军事承诺，特别是在更广泛的中东地区。 “通过摧毁共和党建制派，并重新配置共和党的选举基础，特朗普为比他更激进的限制者获得显赫地位和影响力打开了空间，”美国企业研究所的马修·康蒂内蒂说道。

;

;然而，特朗普先生也有很多优先主义时刻。他相信强大的军事力量，呼应里根“通过实力实现和平”的呼吁。他因叙利亚使用化学武器而对其进行轰炸，并下令暗杀卡西姆·苏莱马尼，后者协调充当伊朗代理人的外国民兵。作为真正的优先考虑者，他作为总统对中国投入的关注远多于欧洲或中东。

;

;在某种程度上，这可能是这是因为特朗普先生从商业角度看待外交事务，将其视为利润和损失的来源。他认为贸易逆差是“不公平”做法的结果（大多数经济学家将其视为不同国家不同储蓄和投资水平的反映）。特朗普先生在会见外国领导人之前常常会问助手：“贸易逆差是多少？”他还对那些在享受美国安全保障的同时却在国防上吝啬的盟友感到不满，声称“世界在嘲笑我们。”

;

;与优先论者和优先论者一样，特朗普也会支持强有力的防御。军备控制可能会进一步受到削弱，因为这三个派别都不会支持它。特朗普政府可能不会续签新《削减战略武器条约》，该条约限制远程核武器，将于 2026 年到期，部分原因是俄罗斯放弃了其中的许多条款，而主要是因为中国正在迅速扩大其库存。

;

;让俄罗斯再次伟大

;

;美国优先实际上已成为现实，“欧洲最后”——限制者和优先者都同意这一观点。 YouGov 民意调查发现，更多的特朗普主义者、“让美国再次伟大”(;MAGA);共和党人对;北约;的看法是不利的，而不是有利的。在其他共和党人中，情况则相反。同样，与非;MAGA;共和党人相比，;MAGA;共和党人不太可能将俄罗斯视为“敌人”（见图表）。

;;
;;
;

;优先论者仍占主导地位的参议院最近通过了一项两党法案，以提供更多军事援助乌克兰（以及以色列和台湾）。但众议院（让“让我们再次伟大”派拥有更大影响力）几个月来一直阻止援助。他们认为，美国必须首先对跨越美国南部边境的移民采取严格限制（尽管在特朗普先生的敦促下，他们拒绝了参议院两党提出的这样做的提议）。

;

;因此，弹药匮乏的乌克兰军队面临压力。特朗普对流血事件表示担忧，并承诺在一天内解决冲突。如何？被提名为特朗普可能的国家安全顾问的<小>;AFPI;的基思·凯洛格将军主张采取胡萝卜加大棒的做法：告诉乌克兰，如果它拒绝谈判达成协议，它将失去美国的支持，并且警告俄罗斯，如果克里姆林宫不同意合理条件，美国将向乌克兰提供更多更好的武器。其他人，如匈牙利总理欧尔班·维克多（Viktor Orban）和美国极端保守派的宠儿，则认为特朗普会干脆放弃乌克兰。无论哪种方式，单靠优先论者都没有足够的影响力来维持拜登政府的慷慨援助。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;除了乌克兰，特朗普表示他不会为“违法者”辩护 ;北约;盟友（那些在国防上花费的<小>;国内生产总值的至少2％;的国家）：“事实上，我会鼓励[俄罗斯人]为所欲为”。博尔顿和埃斯珀认为特朗普可能完全离开<小>;北约;。卢比奥先生否认了这种风险。至上主义者看到了吓唬欧洲人采取更多行动的好处，但会在放弃;北约;方面划清界限。事实上，卢比奥先生帮助推动了要求参议院批准退出联盟的立法。然而，国会无法阻止特朗普如此彻底地破坏<小>;北约;（例如，通过从欧洲撤军），这无异于离开。

;

;凯洛格先生就是其中之一，他表示，未达到支出目标的国家违反了;北约;条约第3条，该条要求盟国拥有“抵抗的能力”武装攻击”，因此不应受益于第五条，该条认为对一个人的攻击就是对所有人的攻击。 “我们不会放弃他们；他们正在放弃我们，”他说。与此同时，另一个特朗普主义智库“美国复兴中心”发表了文章，主张建立“休眠”的<小>;北约;，即美国将从欧洲撤出地面部队，同时保留核保护伞。鉴于这些分歧，尚不清楚特朗普第二届政府会走多远，但;北约;的剧变似乎不可避免。

;

;但也存在一些分歧。因该地区长期冲突而伤痕累累，限制者和优先者都希望避免与伊朗发生战争，因此在抵御亲伊朗民兵方面可能不会像拜登那样积极。他们也不喜欢沙特阿拉伯为与以色列建立关系而付出的代价：与美国签订正式的防务条约。此外，在国会，针对以色列的一揽子援助计划的尝试失败了，部分原因是共和党财政鹰派要求采取措施支付费用，例如削减美国税收机构国税局的资金。

;

;至于特朗普先生，他对以色列总理本雅明内塔尼亚胡怀恨在心，因为他欣然接受了拜登先生在2020年的选举胜利。但最近特朗普先生宣称，“任何投票给民主党的犹太人都讨厌他们的宗教。”由于特朗普喜欢冒险、非正统的峰会，2019 年在比亚里茨举行的七国集团会议期间，他差点会见伊朗时任总统哈桑·鲁哈尼。优先论者都朝着不同的方向发展，而特朗普本人的观点也不一致，令人困惑。

;

;当谈到亚洲时，有关于中国构成的威胁的广泛共识，但不一定是关于如何应对的共识。根据 YouGov 的说法，大多数共和党人，尤其是那些具有;MAGA;倾向的共和党人，将中国定义为“敌人”。

;

;鹰派优先考虑者希望集中精力确保台湾有足够的武装来防御中国的入侵，而美国也有力量来帮助它。不过，在这方面，特朗普先生看起来像是一个限制者。博尔顿回忆道，在椭圆形办公室里，这位前总统会指着他的记号笔尖，将其比作台湾。然后他会指着巨大的Resolute办公桌说：“这就是中国。”特朗普先生还指责台湾实际上窃取了美国的半导体产业。

;

;这位前总统更热衷于贸易战，而不是开枪。 。尽管他可能会再次面临里根派担心经济损失的内部反对，但特朗普克服了困难。在他的第一个任期内，经济顾问抵制用更高的关税轰炸朋友和敌人。他可能会在第二次使用更重的枪支。他提议对所有进口产品统一征收 10% 的关税。他的前贸易代表罗伯特·莱特希泽(Robert Lighthizer)似乎有望获得最高职位，他认为关税应该继续上升，直到美国的贸易逆差被消除。他希望对中国商品征收 60% 的关税，高于目前的 19%。尽管如此，内部人士表示，特朗普仍在寻求与中国领导人习近平达成引人注目的贸易协议。他还希望重新谈判条款; 与欧盟，他厌恶欧盟“比中国更糟糕，只是更小”。

;

;美国的近邻和最大的贸易国加拿大和墨西哥等合作伙伴也有很多值得担心的事情。普遍关税将违反;USMCA;，这是;NAFTA;的调整版本，特朗普先生称赞这是一项“令人惊叹的协议”。然而，贸易并不是唯一的摩擦来源：共和党人谴责墨西哥是移民过境国和毒品（尤其是芬太尼）的来源国。特朗普先生曾经考虑过向墨西哥药物实验室发射导弹。其他人建议部署海军拦截运往墨西哥途中用于制造芬太尼的化学品，甚至派遣特种部队打击贩毒团伙。可以肯定的是，至少与墨西哥的关系会受到影响。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;在顾问中进行裁决并不是特朗普制定外交政策时面临的唯一困难。他还可能面临官僚机构的阻力。特朗普派智囊团正忙于审查候选人，以填补总统礼物中的 4,000 多个职位，其中约 1,200 个职位还需要参议院的批准。

;

;一些人担心特朗普可能会清洗部分或全部美国高级将领，他认为这些将军太觉醒了。他曾谈到使用军队镇压骚乱者或抗议者。与特朗普关系疏远的前国防部长之一埃斯珀表示，将军们可能会收到“可怕但合法”的命令，并且会分散他们对威慑和打击外国敌人这一主要军事任务的注意力。

;< p data-component="paragraph" class="css-121tnhw e1tt35bk0">;国会的组成也将塑造特朗普的团队。如果民主党克服困难保住了参议院，那么只有相当温和的高级职位提名人才能赢得参议院的批准。如果共和党在众议院获得多数席位，更多有争议的人物可能会获得认可。无论如何，特朗普任命的代理官员可以在未经参议院确认的情况下任职数月。

;

;那些与特朗普关系密切的人预测很多湍流。一位人士表示：“他会说很多让人紧张的话，但那是因为他会说实话或通过谈判来清理很多混乱。”

;
;;
;

;美国的朋友应该做什么？ “倾听他的意见，尊重他并寻求妥协，”内部人士建议。许多政府确实在寻求与他的随从中顺从的成员交朋友。其他人将在美国企业和可能在任何贸易战中受到损害的国家中寻找盟友。还有一些人会试图打击他的自负。英国王室让他惊叹不已；法国举行阅兵式。

;

;德国和日本的不同经验具有启发性。在特朗普的第一个任期内，两国都对美国拥有巨额贸易顺差，但在国防方面的支出却少得可怜。特朗普与安格拉·默克尔(Angela Merkel)相处得非常糟糕，但与当时各自的领导人安倍晋三(Abe Shinzo)却出奇地好。为什么？部分原因是日本做出了一些贸易让步，而安倍晋三被称为国防鹰派，而默克尔则是“一块石头”。

;

;宣告美国再次伟大

;

;安倍先生也理解特朗普先生爱奉承的弱点。他死后的回忆录充满了秘诀：与特朗普先生的精心会面，包括他喜欢的活动（很多高尔夫，一次是和一位日本职业选手），他最喜欢的食物（汉堡），金光闪闪（镀金俱乐部），盛况（会见特朗普）皇帝）和娱乐（场边相扑）。 “创造一个我们可以交谈的环境非常重要，”安倍写道。特朗普“对任何需要花钱的事情都持谨慎态度，并从经济角度考虑外交和安全”。华盛顿一位紧张的大使提出了一种完全不同的策略：“你知道如何祈祷吗？” ;■;

;

; drax在下一阶段的作用但是，过渡是不确定的。政府正在考虑是否延长对该工厂的补贴。目前的安排是，如果批发电价低于设定水平，则向 Drax 一次性付款，该安排将于 2027 年结束。延期后，其所有者 Drax 集团将获得延期，该集团在北美和北美洲也拥有生物质发电厂。苏格兰的水力发电厂，是时候用碳捕获和存储装置适合该工厂的时间。

;
;
;
; ; ;

;原则上，用碳捕获和存储（; beccs） ;）可能是电力的碳阴性形式。只要树木变成木材颗粒，像德拉克斯这样的植物的排放量很低（主要是从木头到燃烧器）。如果从燃烧的颗粒中释放出的碳也被捕获并存储在地下，则可能会产生负排放。德拉克斯（Drax）计划将碳捕获到北海下方的耗尽的燃气库中，这是“东海岸集群”的一部分，这是一项基于政府的计划，旨在清除亨伯斯塔（Humber）河口和蒂赛德（Teesside）的工业心脏地带生产的二氧化碳。;

;在实践中，是否; beccs ;是否碳阴性取决于如何收集原始生物质。德拉克斯从森林的美国进口了木材颗粒，而不是裸露英国。绿色类型越过跨大西洋收获的树木可能不会可持续地重新种植。在国外森林砍伐的任何排放量不包括英国碳足迹；国家审计办公室的一份支出监管机构的报告得出的结论是，对供应链的监督不足。非营利组织Ember的Philip MacDonald说，即使所有的木材都是充分的，木材也可以用于燃烧以外的其他目的。

;

;风能和太阳能都变得更加便宜，当时Drax获得了最新的补贴，以改装其煤炭单位以燃烧木材。与其他技术相比，生物质能力的潜在效率提高较少：树木是一项成熟的技术，而生长的土地是有限的。目前，Drax的优势是它不取决于阳光，也不取决于吹风。这可能足以使Drax的熔炉燃料到2030年甚至超越；政府已承认，将需要更多的天然气发电厂作为风力发电。但是，如果可以解决电力储存问题，Drax的冷却塔可能会成为另一种纪念碑。 ;■;

But that is the day the Scottish government has chosen finally to bring into effect its Hate Crime and Public Order Act. The law was passed three years ago, but its implementation was delayed by worries about how the police would deal with its expected effects. Critics of the law say the government is still taking the Scottish people for fools.

;

;Scotland already has an offence of “stirring up racial hatred” 。从四月起，基于其他特征（即宗教、年龄、残疾、性取向和变性身份）而使用“威胁或辱骂”行为意图煽动仇恨也将被定为犯罪。 It will also become possible to prosecute people for things they say in the privacy of their own home. Humza Yousaf, Scotland's first minister, has insisted that the threshold for what constitutes stirring up hatred is “incredibly high”. Plenty of critics disagree.

;
;

;
;

;“Discussion or criticism” of protected characteristics is acceptable, and a carve-out has been made that allows Scots to voice “antipathy, dislike, ridicule or insult” for religion.但排除条款不适用于法律规定的其他特征。有些特征根本没有被涵盖在内，最明显的是性和非宗教信仰。 That explains why some of the law's most vocal critics are women who argue that biological sex should take precedence over proclaimed gender identity in areas from sports competitions to changing rooms to prisons. Many of them believe the new law will be weaponised by trans-rights activists to try to silence them.

;

;They are not the only ones to烦恼。苏格兰自由教会的斯蒂芬·艾利森指出，新法案实际上废除了旧的亵渎法。但他说基督徒和穆斯林担心它会被现代版本所取代。 “我们承认，我们的信仰并不被所有人所认同，也不一定被所有人所理解。 However, we should not be criminalised for expressing orthodox Christian beliefs relating to sexuality and gender.”

;“The debate needs to calm down a bit,” says James Chalmers, a legal scholar at the University of Glasgow. “The new law does not change things as much as some people think. ;;I;;n an industrial; estate near Leicester, Geary's Bakeries turns water, salt and Canadian flour into sourdough bread. The dough ferments slowly in a special room, which, for those familiar with the end product, smells like a thousand breakfasts. Baked loaves of various kinds zip along a conveyor belt, where they are classified by automatic cameras and sent one way or another. The bags into which the sliced bread will be packed are opened with little puffs of air. A food associated with finicky artisans has been industrialised.

;

;For most of its existence Geary's Bakeries, a family firm founded in 1906, was a small outfit that supplied shops in the East Midlands. By 2013 it was making loaves for Aldi, a discounter, and employing 83 people. Today most supermarket chains sell the firm's “Jason's Sourdough” bread. The company has expanded quickly to 440 workers, a number that will rise to 500 when a new building is completed. Though small compared with conventional sliced-bread behemoths like Hovis and Warburtons, it is a leader in the bubbly business of making sourdough.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Britain was not a nation of sourdough-chewers until recently. Eliza Acton's “English Bread Book” of 1857 assumed that bakers would leaven their loaves with yeast (which was close to hand in a country fond of beer) or with soda and acid. She knew that Germans made sourdough bread, but described it as “unfavourable”. Two decades ago the California-based La Brea Bakery made an attempt at supplying the country with sourdough bread. So niche and exotic was the product that the bakery made its loaves in America, froze them and transported them to Britain.

;

;Tastes changed gradually as sourdough bread appeared on restaurant menus and in a growing number of posh bakeries.关于其有益健康的特性，人们或多或少地提出了一些令人愉悦的说法（酸面团所含的成分肯定比普通商业面包要少）。然后，可怕的快速变化发生了。 2020 年 3 月，英国人被限制在家中，并减少购买易腐烂的杂货，以免感染 covid-19。由于时间充裕，他们开始在家烘焙，数量之多以至于商店里的酵母都用完了。 One slow and tricky option remained.

;

;The popularity of ;tv; baking shows notwithstanding, Britain is not a nation of home bakers.从来都不是。 “Servant women in abundance appear to think that loaves are made by the baker, as knights are made by the king,” complained William Cobbett, a social reformer, in the early 19th century. And if home-made yeasty bread is a challenge, the naturally leavened kind is even more so.

;

;“People tried to make sourdough, but it's hard,” says Barry Dawber at Geary's Bakeries. With extraordinarily good timing, his firm distributed the first Jason's loaves just as the virus took hold. When people returned to the shops, they fell upon them with relief.

;

;It would not be easy for the biggest bakers to start churning out sourdough loaves even if they wanted to.他们的生产线通常围绕高速混合机和快速打样建立，并不适合它。 So the rise of Geary's Bakeries is likely to continue. Whether Leicestershire will ever become an appellation to rival San Francisco is another matter.;■;

;;T;;he 1950s; were a good decade to be born in Britain.新建立的福利国家确保你的早年没有肮脏的生活。对于少数成功进入大学的幸运儿来说，大学是免费的。 During your peak earning years, taxes plunged thanks to Margaret Thatcher, oil gushing from the North Sea and the restorative effect of the ;EU;'s single market on the sick man of Europe.房价的飙升足以弥补几年来的高利率。 Defined-benefit pension schemes, then still the norm, ensured that retirement would be prosperous.

;

;Whatever this generation wanted, this generation nearly always got 。值得注意的是，如果 20 世纪 50 年代出生的人与同龄人中的大多数人一起投票，他们就会在每次选举中获胜。结果是，与之前或之后的任何一代人相比，婴儿潮一代在福利国家中支付的费用更少，而从福利国家中领取的费用更多。 In 2010 David Willetts, a Tory grandee and self-aware member of this blessed cohort, summed it up best in a book titled: “The Pinch: How the Baby Boomers Took Their Children's Future—And Why They Should Give it Back”.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Now the good times are coming to an end.婴儿潮一代可能会缴纳更多的税，看着其他几代人受益于他们自己从未享受过的福利，并首次面临选举中的失败一方。习惯于一切事情都按自己的方式行事的一代人第一次开始失败。掐指一算已经结束了；动态正在逆转。 Call it the punch.

;

;Jeremy Hunt, the chancellor of the exchequer, landed the first blows.保守党通过让通货膨胀降低税阶门槛值来监督大幅增税。为了减轻他们的痛苦，亨特先生只关注那些处于工作年龄的人缴纳的税款。 Rather than cut income tax, which is paid by everyone from landlord pensioners to students with a bar job, Mr Hunt chopped National Insurance (;ni;) contributions, which are paid only by those under 66. Since November ;ni; contributions have fallen from 12% to 8%, saving workers about £20bn ($25bn; 1% of ;gdp;) a year.所有纳税人都面临着一些痛苦； only younger taxpayers enjoy any relief.

;

;Where the state is expanding into new areas, it is now to the benefit of younger people. Britain has become a literal nanny state: the government will soon cover the bulk of child-care costs for working parents, again due to Mr Hunt's largesse. At £8bn per year—a shade less than the budget for the justice department—this is strikingly generous. The highest earners aside, young parents benefit to the tune of about £6,500 per child. During the pinch, millennials moaned that their parents received perks that they failed to pass on. On child care, the roles are reversed.

;

;Goodies for pensioners are comparatively frugal.亨特先生于3月24日证实，如果再次当选，政府将维持“三重锁定”，即根据通货膨胀率、收入增长率或2.5%中的较高者增加国家养老金。尽管这项政策引发了千禧一代的愤怒，但与最近的赠品相比，它还是便宜的。 Britain's annual pension bill is about £10bn (0.5% of ;GDP;) bigger than it would have been if the state pension had increased by earnings or inflation since 2012. But in the past few months Mr Hunt has set aside the best part of £30bn (1.5% of ;GDP;) a year for tax cuts and freebies for working-age people, with young parents doing best of all. On paper Mr Hunt is a 57-year-old Thatcherite and the finance minister of the Pensioners' Party; in practice, he is Britain's first millennial chancellor.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Politically, the voices of older voters are already fading.妇女反对国家养老金不平等运动组织抱怨说，政府未能正确通知 20 世纪 50 年代出生的女性，国家养老金年龄将从 60 岁提高到 65 岁，而男性开始领取退休金的年龄也与此相同。 In 2019 the Labour Party's leadership declared that the women who missed out should be repaid in full, at a cost of £58bn. Now, even after an ombudsman has suggested they deserve some money (although not £58bn), politicians from both parties offer excuses rather than the promise of juicy payouts.

;

;Then there is the next election.对于婴儿潮一代来说，几乎可以肯定的是，比失败一方的陌生刺痛更重要的是工党最终的打击力度。工党并没有戴上拳击手套，而是仍然否认这一点。 In government it plans to stick with ludicrously austere spending plans put forward by the Conservatives while returning Britain to growth levels last seen in the noughties, when the country hosted some of the world's biggest banks and was still a net energy exporter.

; ;

;An expensive trainer stamping on a human face for ever

;

;Once reality sets in, Labour will face a choice of whom to pummel 。 On the one side are younger voters, who endure high marginal tax rates, have few assets and overwhelmingly vote Labour. On the other are older voters, who revel in much lower marginal rates, have lots of assets and generally will not vote Labour. The politics point in one direction, but so do the practicalities. Older voters will be more heavily taxed for the same reason that Willie Sutton robbed banks: “Because that's where the money is.”

;

;The pinch lasted decades.多年积累的特权需要不少预算才能消除。这一拳将是一个漫长而缓慢的逆转。但这也将是一个熟悉的故事。千禧一代将利用他们的人口比重（到 2020 年，他们的人口规模将超过婴儿潮一代）来重新平衡税收，将负担转移到其他几代人身上，让他们为自己花上福利，就像婴儿潮一代所做的那样。威利茨勋爵在谈到他的婴儿潮一代时写道：“作为伟大的一代人，你会成为一股强大的颠覆力量：你就像洪水冲垮堤岸的河流一样涌入社会。”也许婴儿潮一代和千禧一代毕竟没有那么不同。 Everyone turns into their parents eventually.  ;■;

;Of course French oenophiles—and importers—keep fine wines flowing. Consumption of high-quality wine remains strong. But the decline of cheaper stuff has wider repercussions for France. ;The local elections for mayors and city councils will almost inevitably see Mr Erdogan's Justice and Development (;AK;) party prevail in most parts of the country. ;Turkey's strongman is now determined to take back control of the city and its $16bn budget. One thing standing in his way is the economy. ;Local elections in Turkey are as much about storm drains, bus service and patronage networks as they are about national politics. ;As long as Mrs Aksener is in charge, say her associates, Good will continue to oppose Mr Erdogan.但 3 月 31 日的疲软表现可能会引发领导层挑战、分裂或两者兼而有之。 Some Good politicians remain close to the Nationalist Movement Party (;MHP;), from which Good is descended, and which forms part of Mr Erdogan's governing alliance. “Those people can easily shake hands with Erdogan,” says an ;IYI; insider. “They don't aspire to have popular support, but to have power.” They may soon decide to jump ship.

;A schism has long been evident.一方面，非法移民被视为一个问题，政客们知道“拦船”（或当地采取的一些听起来强硬的措施来遏制新移民）将使他们继续执政。另一方面，欧洲人将自己视为世界上一股正义的力量，与世界各地的国家进行愉快的贸易和外交联盟。几十年来，这两个世界一直是分开的。警察和内政部人员竖起栅栏将移民拒之门外，而外交官、贸易官员和发展专家则向难民来源国提供大量资金、疫苗和甜心贸易协议。在 2015-16 年移民激增以及最近非法入境者数量增加之后，欧洲决定阻止船只比为了自身利益而善待他人更重要。 Foreign policy is being co-opted by the interior-ministry crowd to keep down migrant numbers.

;

;A set of ;EU ;laws due to be adopted in April call for a “comprehensive approach” to tackling migration—ie, one that includes putting pressure on foreign governments to ensure fewer of their people pitch up illegally in Europe. In many ways this will formalise a tactic that has become the norm in recent years. On March 17th the ;EU; agreed to provide over €5bn ($5.4bn) in grants and loans to Egypt, the latest country with a Mediterranean coastline to get money for sealing its borders more effectively. A deal in 2016 with Turkey and one with Tunisia last year served as templates; more are in the works. Their aim is clear: to help stem the flow of people to Europe. Those that can help “externalise” the ;EU;'s migrant problem—for example Turkey, which hosts Syrians who might otherwise end up in Germany—can get even more cash.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;But countries far beyond Europe's shores are also being coerced into helping bring down migrant numbers. Every year around 400,000 foreigners are ordered to leave the ;EU;, often having arrived illegally and failed to convince one of its 27 member states they were entitled to refugee status.其中不到四分之一被驱逐出境，通常是因为他们的祖国——孟加拉国、阿尔及利亚或尼日利亚——不愿将他们遣返。 (Locals in poor countries take pride in having relatives in rich ones who send back remittances even if they work illegally.) The new ;EU; rules foresee faster deportation for arrivals from countries whose citizens are rarely granted refugee status.这需要一条有效的传送带来驱逐那些被视为经济移民的人，而外国政府的帮助是关键。 Hence the new diplomatic deal: help us, or else.

;

;Under the ;EU;'s new approach, governments refusing to readmit their own citizens can be punished. One sanction is to make it harder for people in those places to get visas for ;EU; countries.另一个是削减发展援助，这是对埃塞俄比亚等国的威胁。 A decades-old scheme that lets the world's 60 or so poorest countries export goods to Europe with no or low tariffs—a key poverty-reduction measure—could soon become conditional on those countries doing the ;EU;'s bidding when it comes to refugees. Help us with migration or face import taxes, in other words.

;;

;Help me help me help you

;

;Critics say imposing conditions on aid, trade and visas is unconscionable. “Europe is putting its short-term migration priorities ahead of the development needs of some of the world's poorest countries,” says Nadine Biehler of the German Institute for International and Security Affairs.与埃及和突尼斯等国的大笔交易也昂贵得令人眼花缭乱。 They help keep in power strongmen who will slow down their countries' development.以这种方式为援助设定条件违反了原则，即受援者而不是捐助者应该控制资金的去向。 Diplomats grouse that it is hard to convince an African country to help Europe when canvassing for votes against Russia in the ;UN;, for example, while also threatening them.

;

;The interior-ministry faction who are the main proponents of the new approach have routed the opposition.在一个右翼民粹主义者在民意调查中不断上升的政体中，移民是一个政治优先事项，而外国援助则不是。用帮助整合外交和移民政策的欧盟委员玛格丽特·希纳斯 (Margaritis Schinas) 的话来说，欧洲正在从“天真时代走向自信时代”。老派的贸易、发展和外交类型认为这都是肮脏的交易，但他们知道除了向专栏作家抱怨之外，他们对此无能为力。 Pragmatists in the development bureaucracy of the ;EU ;well understand that being seen to help reduce migration is a good way to keep scarce funding.他们描绘了欧洲与贫穷国家之间更广泛的“伙伴关系”的图景，其中移民只是其中的一个方面。 Plenty of schools and irrigation systems will still get built, in other words—as long as you do what we ask first.;■;

;;T;;he night ;of June 1st 2020 was a chaotic one in Chicago. A week earlier, George Floyd had been murdered by a Minneapolis police officer, and protests against police brutality had spread all over the world. A day before, the then mayor, Lori Lightfoot, had requested help from the National Guard for the first time since the riots of 1968. Such was the situation when Heriberto Carbajal-Flores, a then-28-year-old carpenter, borrowed a gun and joined a group of men defending a tyre shop in Little Village, a Mexican neighbourhood, from would-be looters. At around 11pm, in full view of a camera, Mr Carbajal-Flores shot seven times in the direction of a white car that was speeding past. Forty minutes later, he was arrested.

;

;So far, just another story of madness on that hot summer night. But Mr Carbajal-Flores's rather reckless defence of property may yet change America. In early March the last of the charges originally filed against him was dismissed by a federal judge in Chicago. Mr Carbajal-Flores, a Mexican citizen who arrived illegally in America as a child, was accused of breaking the federal law which bans undocumented immigrants (as well as foreigners on temporary visas) from owning guns. The judge, Sharon Johnson Coleman, ruled that, as applied to him, the law was unconstitutional. Citing cases of former British loyalists in the revolutionary war who were allowed guns, she argued that Mr Carbajal-Flores was entitled to an “individualised assessment” about whether he had a right to own a gun; and in his case, he did.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;In effect, Ms Coleman ruled that some undocumented immigrants are allowed to have guns.尽管几乎肯定会被上诉，但这项裁决已经在共和党人中掀起了一场风暴。来自佛罗里达州的共和党参议员马可·卢比奥（Marco Rubio）想知道这项裁决“是否是为了嘲笑枪支法以及对作为美国公民的价值的整体理解”。 It shows how one conservative priority, the right to gun ownership with few restrictions, may be about to crash into another: a strong dislike of undocumented migrants.

;

;A generation ago the idea that a Mexican illegally in America could have a constitutional right to carry a gun would have been considered absurd. Yet the question has arisen thanks to conservative rulings at the Supreme Court that have widened the scope of the Second Amendment, which gives Americans the right to bear arms.

;

;First, in 2008 there was ;District of Columbia v Heller;, which ruled that a ban on handguns in the nation's capital was unconstitutional. Then, in 2022, came ;New York State Rifle & Pistol Association Inc. v Bruen, ;which ruled that requiring individuals to show “proper cause” to get a concealed-carry permit was also unconstitutional, along with any gun-control law lacking an analogue in 1791. Now the Second Amendment is, in the words of Justice Clarence Thomas, no longer “a second-class right” to be given at the discretion of officials. Rather, it is comparable to, say, the First Amendment, which protects freedom of speech and religion.

;

;Yet the constitution says that the right to bear arms is held by “the people”, and not merely by citizens. Mr Carbajal-Flores's lawyers argue that their client is a member of “the people” by virtue of his ties to the United States. Though he entered America illegally, he is eligible for protection from deportation under ;daca;, an executive order signed into effect by Barack Obama.他被捕后的周末，他与相恋多年的美国公民女友结婚了。他的孩子是公民。他们还认为，他专门使用武器来阻止抢劫者，这正是许多保守派所钦佩的行为。卡巴哈尔-弗洛雷斯表示，警方指示他携带武器，他开枪是警告性的。 “Our client is a legitimate hero,” says Ross Cassingham, one of Mr Carbajal-Flores's lawyers. “He's the proverbial good guy with a gun.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;At appeal the government's lawyers are likely to say otherwise. In their response to the defence's first motion to dismiss, they noted that Mr Carbajal-Flores armed himself before he even spoke to the police and suggested his gunfire was not obviously intended only to warn, so he was not acting in legitimate self-defence. They also argued that the law banning undocumented migrants from owning guns is constitutional, on the basis that the ;Heller ;decision still allowed the government to restrict classes of people from owning firearms. And they contended that restrictions on non-citizens are legitimate, on the basis that people who have already broken the law in moving to the country cannot be trusted with firearms. That argument was initially accepted.

;

;But that came before ;Bruen;, which in effect established a test that gun laws must be in line with the laws of the early republic. Hence Judge Coleman's consideration of how British loyalists were treated after the revolutionary war. In the late 18th century, notes Adam Winkler, of the University of California, Los Angeles, School of Law, the concept of illegal immigration hardly existed, and so “the people” included everybody inside the United States. “It is clear that undocumented immigrants have a right to free speech and free religion,” says Mr Winkler. “So for purposes of consistency, one would imagine they would have Second Amendment rights.”

;

;What happens next? Another case in the Supreme Court will soon decide whether domestic abusers under restraining orders can be restricted from owning guns; that may give some hints as to how the Carbajal-Flores case could be resolved. A final decision could have big implications. At the moment, for example, the state of Illinois requires anyone who wants a gun to apply for a licence, and bans foreigners without green cards from applying. If upheld, this ruling could force the state to consider almost anyone. Hence the outrage of people like Mr Rubio.

;

;Yet as Mr Winkler notes, there is an irony to the backlash. Conservatives usually argue that gun-control laws do not stop criminals from buying guns anyway. But then conservatives have not always been so keen on widespread gun rights—at least when people they dislike start exercising them. In 1967 California banned the carrying of loaded guns, in an attempt to disarm the rifle-carrying Black Panther Party. The governor who signed the law was none other than Ronald Reagan. Views on guns can change, even among Republicans. ;■;

;;“T;;HAT PUNK; pulled a Glock,” says Bruce Willis's character in the action-packed 1990s Christmas classic “Die Hard 2”. “你知道那是什么吗？”你也许会这么做。警察腰上的那把枪？ It's probably a pistol made by Glock, an Austrian manufacturer. That weapon in John Wick's hands during a heart-thumping scene?其中之一肯定是格洛克。从执法部门到好莱坞的违法者，格洛克在流行文化中无处不在。它们也是现实生活中罪犯的首选枪支。 Which makes the fact that they can so easily be turned into machineguns that much more worrying.

;

;On March 19th the city of Chicago filed a lawsuit against Glock.犯罪分子利用廉价的附加组件将格洛克手枪改造成机枪。这种非法装置被称为自动烙铁，但它也被称为“格洛克开关”，尽管格洛克并不制造它们。 They are the size of a large coin, and they can be bought for less than a hardback book, or made at home by anyone with a 3;D; printer for much less.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The lawsuit, filed together with Everytown Law, a group of litigators specialising in gun reform, claims that Glock knows about the problem but has failed to prevent it anyway. Everytown Law 的执行董事 Eric Tirschwell 表示：“没有其他手枪设计能够如此轻松地转换为机关枪。” “So why haven't they fixed theirs?”

;

;Chicago is notorious for its street violence, and the pandemic only made things worse.尽管2023年枪击事件比2022年下降了13%，但该市仍面临枪支暴力浪潮。去年，有 600 多人被谋杀，但并非全部是被枪杀的，还有 2,400 多起非致命枪击事件。芝加哥市声称格洛克让本来就糟糕的情况变得更糟。 The lawsuit states that between 2021 and 2023, 1,100 modified Glocks were recovered by Chicago's police.

;

;The National Rifle Association, America's gun lobby, disagrees with blaming Glock. “Chicago's focus ought to be on the criminals,” says Andrew Arulanandam, the group's interim ;CEO;. “Without criminals, there is less crime.”

;

;The Windy City is not alone in facing a barrage of bullets. The District of Columbia and others have also reported problems with these illegal add-ons. Chicago is the first city to sue over the devices. The lawsuit is made possible by the Illinois Firearms Industry Responsibility Act, a state law passed last year that allows gun manufacturers to be sued for public harm, but it also rests on a federal law prohibiting machineguns. This suit may be the first of its kind, but it probably won't be the last. ;■;

;;O; ;n the last; Sunday of Black History Month there was real energy in Atlanta's Ebenezer Baptist Church. ;

;The night before a very different set of black Georgians had come together.在一座改建的市中心仓库里，佐治亚州黑人共和党委员会举办了有史以来的第一次化装舞会。牧场主和代表上台发表特朗普式演讲。 Women dressed in red sequinned gowns and fur stoles nibbled at fried chicken while chatting about their plans to get friends to break with tradition and vote Republican in November.

;At roughly 30%, Georgia has the highest share of black voters of any battleground state.过去二十年里，黑人涌入亚特兰大都会区，使佐治亚州成为民主党可以竞争的唯一南方腹地州。2020 年，乔·拜登成为自 1992 年以来第一位在该州获胜的民主党总统候选人。但随着拜登与特朗普的复赛， looming, Democrats fear they are losing ground with their most loyal voting bloc.

;

;In the decade to 2023 the share of black men who identified as Democrats fell from 80% to 62% nationwide.对于女性来说，这一比例从 84% 下降到 74%。黑人年轻人对拜登先生尤其不感兴趣。 Republicans in Georgia see an opportunity. The governor's race in 2022 was the first time that both candidates actively chased black voters.史黛西·艾布拉姆斯花费了 1 亿美元来讨好他们，而最终击败她的布莱恩·坎普则部署了黑人代理人，在黑人拥有的企业中开展竞选活动，并强调了他任命黑人法官的记录。 In December a group of Democratic strategists published a report warning that even the slightest drop in black turnout this year could hand Donald Trump a victory in the state.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Georgia's black Republicans think three issues can sway their brethren: education, crime and immigration. Mesha Mainor, a state representative who left the Democratic Party in July to become a Republican, says that black pupils suffer disproportionately from failing public schools. Last year Atlanta's white high-school graduation rate was 12 percentage points above the black one. 3 月 20 日，州参议院通过了一项法案，向家庭提供 6,500 美元的私立学校学费代金券。 She thinks Republicans' crusade for school choice should help them pick up voters of all political stripes.

;;

;Angry about the border

;

;On crime black communities tend not to favour liberal policies—and Georgia Republicans plan to capitalise on that. For the past year Atlanta has been divided over a plan to build a $90m police-training facility dubbed “cop city” by protesters. Notably, a black councilwoman proposed it, the city's black mayor has endorsed it and an Emory University survey from last year found that a minority of black residents opposed it. Jalen Johnson, a deputy sheriff and city commissioner in Albany, Georgia, says he can't remember a single time he has delivered a death notification to a white family. Republican tough-on-crime policies, he says, resonate more when it's always “black boys getting shot”. He notes that during Mr Trump's presidency there was also real progress on prison reform.

;

;Days after a Venezuelan immigrant was arrested for killing a nursing student in Athens in late February, Kelly Loeffler, who lost her Senate seat to Mr Warnock three years ago, convened a meeting at a renowned Atlanta soul-food restaurant. Over dinner black panellists spoke about how resentful they feel about Mr Biden's policies towards people who cross the southern border illegally. Black Georgians have watched loved ones go to jail for dealing marijuana, one said, while migrants who break the law by sneaking into America walk free and are even rewarded with government and non-profit aid. They hope to drum up that same anger in black Democrats in this cycle.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The swing state's black electorate still leans overwhelmingly left.但已皈依保守派的年轻格鲁吉亚黑人却一心想传福音。一群女大学生在化装舞会上表示，她们将不再容忍候选人认为自己的选票是理所当然的。 For some it was Ms Abrams, a prominent black Democrat who ran for Georgia's governor twice, who taught them that they, too, have a voice in politics. When they thought about it, they realised they were being played by their party.

;

;“A lot of times it started with a brother,” says Michaelah Montgomery, a 25-year-old who grew up during Barack Obama's presidency and now runs the Atlanta chapter of an organisation called ;BLEXIT;. “我们都信任他，因为他看起来像我们，并且在我们的教堂演讲。”但这还不够。如果说她和担心失去佐治亚州的民主党战略家能就一件事达成一致的话，那就是拜登今年将不得不花更多的钱、更加努力地争取黑人选票。 The days of the token fish fry are over. ;■;

;;A; ;lmost 30 years; ago, in May 1994, a former Arkansas state clerk, Paula Jones, filed a sexual-harassment suit against President Bill Clinton. She said that in 1991, as governor of Arkansas, he lured her to a hotel room in Little Rock, pushed down his trousers and urged her to perform a sex act, but she rebuffed him.

;

;Mr Clinton denied the story, and his lawyers said he was immune to civil litigation while in office. A federal judge eventually threw out Ms Jones's claim, but not before the Supreme Court rejected Mr Clinton's argument about immunity, finding—hilariously—that the suit would be a minimal distraction. In fact, information was secretly passing between the investigation by Ken Starr, the independent counsel in the ever-branching inquiry known as Whitewater, and Ms Jones's lawyers.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Those lawyers asked during Mr Clinton's deposition in the Jones case whether he had been involved with a White House intern, Monica Lewinsky, and his denial led to the charges of perjury and obstruction for which the Republican House of Representatives impeached him. 1999年，参议院通过两党投票宣告他无罪。对于像列克星敦这样的人来说，在那些年里艰难地经历了性、政治和法律的泥沼，然后在 2001 年 9 月 11 日明亮晴朗的早晨抬头思考自己是否一直都把自己的优先事项放在正确的位置上，很难不看a new documentary about Stephanie Clifford, “Stormy”, without some sense of déjà vu.

;

;Ms Clifford, who performed under the name Stormy Daniels as a stripper and porn actress, has said Donald Trump had sex with her during a celebrity golf tournament in 2006. On the eve of the presidential election in 2016 Mr Trump's lawyer, Michael Cohen, paid Ms Clifford $130,000 to sign a non-disclosure agreement 。 Mr Trump has denied Ms Clifford's story but acknowledged he reimbursed Mr Cohen, to stifle her “false and extortionist accusations”. That reimbursement is the basis for what will be the first-ever criminal trial of an American president, if it starts as scheduled next month. The Manhattan district attorney, Alvin Bragg, has accused Mr Trump of falsifying business records in order to commit another crime he has not specified, but which appears to be violating federal election law.

;

;Probably because this episode involves Mr Trump and has played out in the social-media era, the drama seems even tawdrier and the price paid by the woman at the centre seems even greater than in the saga of Ms Jones. Ms Clifford now owes Mr Trump more than $600,000 because she lost a defamation suit against him and is liable for his lawyer's fees. She has said her lawyer filed the suit against her wishes.

;
;
;
;
;

;

;Like Ms Jones, Ms Clifford, who grew up poor in Baton Rouge, Louisiana, was assailed as trailer trash, a gold-digger and a slut.与琼斯女士一样，注册共和党人克利福德女士表示，她没有政治议程。两者都被一些看似盟友的人利用。和琼斯女士一样，克利福德女士也受到她的新名人的鼓舞（并受到攻击）。 After the ;Wall Street Journal ;revealed her claims about Mr Trump in January 2018, she embarked on a “Making America Horny Again” strip tour and discovered older women and gay men crowding her venues. “This is going to be the best day of my life,” she says in “Stormy”, with touching sincerity, as she prepares to appear on “Saturday Night Live”.

;

;But the picture, never bright, steadily darkens during the documentary. Ms Clifford stays on the road not only to pay her bills but to protect her daughter from the uproar. Her marriage disintegrates. The lawyer who filed the defamation suit, Michael Avenatti, turns out to have embezzled from her (he is serving 19 years for crimes against her and other clients). Her book royalties dry up as fans realise their money might go to Mr Trump. Then Mr Bragg files his charges, and the insults on social media turn to death threats. Ms Clifford is shown, near tears, reading some aloud: “Kill yourself” and “You just signed your death warrant.”

;

;Not just for the right but for the left it can seem as if history started anew with Mr Trump. In the documentary the precedent of the Clinton era goes unexplored. It ought to make just about everyone squirm. The establishment news media was less fascinated by Ms Jones at first than it was by Ms Clifford. Back then it was Republicans who were scandalised by the president, while Democrats, including many feminists, were scandalised by the women who accused him. Then it was a conservative prosecutor who seemed determined to whipsaw a civil complaint into criminal charges; now it is a progressive prosecutor electing to test a novel legal theory against a former president, after federal prosecutors chose not to pursue a similar case. Back then the accused claimed to be the victim and turned the prosecutor's choice to his political advantage. So far that history is repeating itself.

;Eye of the Stormy

;

;Poignantly, the one person in “Stormy ” heard questioning their choices is Ms Clifford.她说她不是受害者，当特朗普先生在她以为的晚餐约会期间寻求性行为让她感到惊讶时，她答应了。 She says Mr Trump “wasn't wrong” when he was overheard saying, on the infamous “Access Hollywood” tape, that women would let him do what he wanted. “这一切中最困难的部分是，我觉得我对每一个可能追随我的女人负有部分责任，”她说，这是一种残酷的自我审视，渴望这个悲伤故事中的其他人来代替.

;

;Even allowing for the documentary's sympathetic viewpoint, Ms Clifford's courage is unmistakable. She says she will not give up “because I'm telling the truth”.但她为吞噬她生命的愤怒提供了毁灭性的尾声。 “这毫无意义，”她说。 “I have no hope at all, any more.” ;■;
